abstract: In 25 years of independence, Bangladesh has been plagued by wars, violent coups and military dictatorships. But last month the nation opened a potentially hopeful period by holding the most peaceful election in its history, with nearly three-quarters of eligible voters going to the polls. The winner was the left-of-center Awami League led by Sheik Hasina Wazed, whose father brought the  nation to independence in 1971. If Mrs. Wazed honors her pledge to govern by accommodation and with moderate economic policies, Bangladesh could emerge with  stronger democratic institutions and economic conditions.         The return to power by Mrs. Wazed's party is a poignant moment for Bangladesh. In 1971, when Bangladesh was the eastern portion of Pakistan, the league was led by her father, Sheik Mujibur Rahman. His victory in parliamentary elections that year was rejected by the Pakistani leadership in the western half of the country, prompting an invasion of eastern Pakistan by India that split Pakistan asunder. Sheik Mujib, as he is known, ruled the newly created nation of Bangladesh ruthlessly. In 1975 he and more than a dozen family members and aides were murdered in a coup by army officers, setting off two decades of political turmoil.
lead_paragraph: In 25 years of independence, Bangladesh has been plagued by wars, violent coups and military dictatorships. But last month the nation opened a potentially hopeful period by holding the most peaceful election in its history, with nearly three-quarters of eligible voters going to the polls. The winner was the left-of-center Awami League led by Sheik Hasina Wazed, whose father brought the nation to independence in 1971. If Mrs. Wazed honors her pledge to govern by accommodation and with moderate economic policies, Bangladesh could emerge with stronger democratic institutions and economic conditions.

headline.main: New Hope for Bangladesh
headline.print_headline: New Hope for Bangladesh

abstract: A storm in the Bay of Bengal has sunk 18 fishing trawlers, killing at least 16 people, a fishing community spokesman said today. A hundred people are missing.         The storm and monsoon floods battering India and Bangladesh, together with disease blamed on the deluge, have now killed at least 291 people in two weeks.
lead_paragraph: A storm in the Bay of Bengal has sunk 18 fishing trawlers, killing at least 16 people, a fishing community spokesman said today. A hundred people are missing.

headline.main: World News Briefs;Storms in Bay of Bengal Kill Almost 300 People
headline.print_headline: World News Briefs;Storms in Bay of Bengal Kill Almost 300 People

abstract: A tornado that struck northern Bangladesh on Monday killed at least 443 people and injured more than 32,000, local officials said today.         It took the tornado less than a half an hour to flatten 80 villages, killing  scores of people with scraps of tin roofs and tree branches transformed into missiles by the 125 mile-per-hour winds.
lead_paragraph: A tornado that struck northern Bangladesh on Monday killed at least 443 people and injured more than 32,000, local officials said today.

headline.main: Death Toll in Bangladesh Tornado Rises to at Least 443
headline.print_headline: Death Toll in Bangladesh Tornado Rises to at Least 443

abstract: Nearly 21 years after it lost its leader and its grip on power in an army massacre, the Awami League, the political party that won Bangladesh its independence from Pakistan, returned from the political wilderness today as the  winner of a general election.         The new Prime Minister is almost certain to be Sheik Hasina Wazed, 48, who was one of only two members of the immediate family to escape the attack in 1975 that killed her father, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the first Prime Minister and later President of Bangladesh. Mrs. Wazed greeted the victory today at a home in the Dhalmondi district in Dhaka, a few hundred yards from the house, now a memorial, where her father and more than a dozen other relatives died in a hail of automatic fire.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 21 years after it lost its leader and its grip on power in an army massacre, the Awami League, the political party that won Bangladesh its independence from Pakistan, returned from the political wilderness today as the winner of a general election.

headline.main: After 21 Years, Bangladeshi Party Is Returned to Power
headline.print_headline: After 21 Years, Bangladeshi Party Is Returned to Power

abstract: There are no brownstones in Bangladesh.         But in the brownstone corridors of Brooklyn, the men who wipe grime off the aging stone buildings, restore their cracking stoops and spruce up their cornices are increasingly immigrants from Bangladesh.

abstract: Mohammed Uddin was sound asleep in his Queens apartment when he got the call. The Government was giving out green cards at the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service offices in Manhattan, his friend told him.         In a flash, Mr. Uddin was dressing and kissing his wife goodbye. By 1:30 A.M. yesterday, he was in a taxi, racing toward downtown.

abstract: The army sent medical teams and soldiers to northern Bangladesh today to help tens of thousands of people injured by a tornado and to search for 500 others who are still missing.         Authorities said 508 people were killed and 33,000 injured by the tornado, which swept through 80 villages in the northern plains on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The army sent medical teams and soldiers to northern Bangladesh today to help tens of thousands of people injured by a tornado and to search for 500 others who are still missing.

abstract: For more than two decades, the political life of Bangladesh has been roiled by an event of shocking violence, the assassination of the country's founding leader, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, and more than a dozen of his family members and aides.   The army officers who carried out the killings on Aug. 15, 1975, set loose political demons that after 15 years of military rule, assassinations and lawlessness have still not fully let go of the country's fate.
lead_paragraph: For more than two decades, the political life of Bangladesh has been roiled by an event of shocking violence, the assassination of the country's founding leader, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, and more than a dozen of his family members and aides.

abstract: The insatiable thirst of the world's burgeoning billions has caused a spurt of dam building in temperate regions in the last 40 years, and a scientist with  the space agency has found that the reservoirs are affecting Earth's orbital rotation.         Although Earth's rate of spin is gradually slowing because of the tidal drag  of the moon, the slowing would have been measurably greater if it were not for the influence of 88 reservoirs built since the early 1950's, said the scientist, Dr. Benjamin Fong Chao, a geophysicist at the Goddard Space Flight Center, an arm of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in Greenbelt, Md. Each  of the reservoirs contains at least 2.4 cubic miles of water weighing 10 billion metric tons. The reservoirs contain the bulk of the world's impounded water.
lead_paragraph: The insatiable thirst of the world's burgeoning billions has caused a spurt of dam building in temperate regions in the last 40 years, and a scientist with the space agency has found that the reservoirs are affecting Earth's orbital rotation.

headline.main: Dams for Water Supply Are Altering Earth's Orbit, Expert Says

abstract: Paul Goldberger reviews exhibit Louis I Kahn Drawings: Synagogue Projects at the Jewish Museum, NYC; drawings (L)
snippet: Paul Goldberger reviews exhibit Louis I Kahn Drawings: Synagogue Projects at the Jewish Museum, NYC; drawings (L)
lead_paragraph: ALL ARCHITECTURE, FOR Louis I. Kahn, was spiritual. The act of entering a work of architecture, the act of contemplating it, above all the act of making it -- these were all parts of a deeply spiritual quest for Kahn, a man who was not religious in the conventional sense but for whom architecture resonated with a passion that made it, for him, a route to the kingdom of heaven.

headline.main: A Spiritual Quest Realized But Not in Stone
headline.print_headline: A Spiritual Quest Realized But Not in Stone

abstract: Each morning, as the smoggy winter dawn begins to lift, thousands of women in colorful saris, some cradling infants, walk in a silent tide along the causeway  leading from the Baridara slum district toward this city's growing network of garment factories.         In poorly lit tenement buildings, the women sit at rows of sewing machines making clothes -- socks and shorts, windbreakers and track suits -- that trade experts say reach one in every five American homes. Last year, factories employing more than a million Bangladeshi women recorded sales to the United States of $1.5 billion, more than 40 percent of Bangladesh's booming export earnings.
lead_paragraph: Each morning, as the smoggy winter dawn begins to lift, thousands of women in colorful saris, some cradling infants, walk in a silent tide along the causeway leading from the Baridara slum district toward this city's growing network of garment factories.

abstract: Africa will need to increase its food production by 300 percent by the year 2050 to satisfy growing population demands, the United Nations' Food and Agriculture Organization said today.         The Rome-based agency said in a statement that a report being prepared with the United Nations Population Fund for a World Food Summit in November says that sharing the world's food more fairly would "probably eliminate most cases of undernourishment."
lead_paragraph: Africa will need to increase its food production by 300 percent by the year 2050 to satisfy growing population demands, the United Nations' Food and Agriculture Organization said today.

abstract: Martha Smith cried as she left the Dover Mills plant of Andover Togs Inc. on  a Wednesday afternoon late in January. Along with approximately 100 other people, she had lost her job sewing children's clothing.         Now she is enrolled in a state-sponsored program to learn clerical skills. "There's no more textile jobs around here," she said. "They are all going to Mexico and overseas."
lead_paragraph: Martha Smith cried as she left the Dover Mills plant of Andover Togs Inc. on a Wednesday afternoon late in January. Along with approximately 100 other people, she had lost her job sewing children's clothing.

abstract: Fifty-three cab drivers, nearly all of them born half a world away, became entrepreneurs yesterday as the winning bidders in New York City's first sale of  new taxi medallions since the Depression.         To the drivers, the prize was nothing short of the essential promise of America: the chance to go into business for themselves after years of working for others. The successful bidders, most from India, Pakistan or Bangladesh, had offered up to $177,000 for the right to work mind-numbing, 70-hour weeks for an income that rarely exceeds $30,000 a year.
lead_paragraph: Fifty-three cab drivers, nearly all of them born half a world away, became entrepreneurs yesterday as the winning bidders in New York City's first sale of new taxi medallions since the Depression.

headline.main: For 53, the Promise of America Fits on a Taxicab
headline.print_headline: For 53, the Promise of America Fits on a Taxicab

abstract: At least 30 children in Haiti have died of acute kidney failure after taking  contaminated liquid acetaminophen made by a pharmaceutical company in Haiti, international health officials said last night.         Haitians traveling in the United States were warned to discard any bottles of liquid acetaminophen bearing the trade names Afebril and Valodon in case they were contaminated, the Pan American Health Organization in Washington said.
lead_paragraph: At least 30 children in Haiti have died of acute kidney failure after taking contaminated liquid acetaminophen made by a pharmaceutical company in Haiti, international health officials said last night.

headline.main: Contaminated Anti-Fever Drug Kills at Least 30 Children in Haiti

snippet: Barbara Crossette article contends that dismissal of Prime Min Benazir Bhutto's autocratic, corruption-riddled Government in Pakistan adds another chapter to checkered history of female political leaders in South Asia; photo of Bhutto and other fe...
lead_paragraph: MORE women have led modern governments in South Asia than in any other region of the world. But as the ignominious dismissal of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's autocratic, corruption-riddled Government in Pakistan last week demonstrates, anyone who would write feminist history needs to look hard at how these powerful women have ruled, and what their exercise of authority has meant to the people they governed.

abstract: The ragged mountains and thick jungles along the Thai-Burmese border, rife with ethnic insurgencies, wandering refugees and smugglers of gems and teakwood, are the world's epicenter of drug-resistant malaria.         As scientists race to produce new anti-malarial drugs, parasites borne by mosquitoes here foil them, developing resistances that have spread across the world and raised fears of a day when some strains of the disease become incurable.
lead_paragraph: The ragged mountains and thick jungles along the Thai-Burmese border, rife with ethnic insurgencies, wandering refugees and smugglers of gems and teakwood, are the world's epicenter of drug-resistant malaria.

abstract: IN 1964, G.L. Soni was an engineering graduate student, newly arrived in Fargo, N.D., from southern India's Kerala state and shocked to find two feet of  snow on the ground and no tandoori anywhere on the horizon. It would be years before the Beatles embraced Ravi Shankar, and mainstream America was clueless when it came to Indian cuisine. "Nobody even knew about yogurt," Mr. Soni recalls.         And like most Indian men, he was clueless himself. Meals had always just appeared before him, cooked unseen by female or servant hands. "I never knew a coriander from a cumin seed," he says. "I didn't know a spice from a lentil."
lead_paragraph: IN 1964, G.L. Soni was an engineering graduate student, newly arrived in Fargo, N.D., from southern India's Kerala state and shocked to find two feet of snow on the ground and no tandoori anywhere on the horizon. It would be years before the Beatles embraced Ravi Shankar, and mainstream America was clueless when it came to Indian cuisine. "Nobody even knew about yogurt," Mr. Soni recalls.

abstract: IN antiquity, before the rise of powerful nation-states, there were city-states whose names identified a civilization -- Athens, Edo, Rome and Alexandria among them. Some experts are now suggesting that in the future, cities, and not nations, will once again define who we are and how we live.         The new megalopolises are not the city-states of old, with their largely homogeneous populations and restricted views of citizenship. Today they are vast, polyglot and sprawling. Richard Sennett of New York University, who has written extensively on urban life, calls them "cities without a center or an edge."
lead_paragraph: IN antiquity, before the rise of powerful nation-states, there were city-states whose names identified a civilization -- Athens, Edo, Rome and Alexandria among them. Some experts are now suggesting that in the future, cities, and not nations, will once again define who we are and how we live.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends;The Return of the City-State
headline.print_headline: Ideas & Trends;The Return of the City-State

abstract: Special Report on AIDS scourge in India; United Nations agencies dealing with AIDS conclude that India will become world center of the disease by end of decade; by then, United Nations estimates indicate, a million Indians will be sick with AIDS, and as many as 10 million will be infected with HIV; a quarter of all projected infections worldwide will be in India; India's five million truck drivers are at center of expected explosion of disease amogn its 970 million people; at places such as Petrapole, vast and chaotic truck stop, where drivers have little to do, it is common for a man to buy sex every day, sometimes several times a day, from local women and teen-age girls for as little as 10 rupees, about 28 cents; social attitudes and taboos that make it difficult to confront AIDS discussed; photos; map (L)
snippet: Special Report on AIDS scourge in India; United Nations agencies dealing with AIDS conclude that India will become world center of the disease by end of decade; by then, United Nations estimates indicate, a million Indians will be sick with AIDS, ...
lead_paragraph: The giant tamarind trees spread a lush umbrella across the highway here, 75 miles from Calcutta on the main road between India and Bangladesh. The shade is the only forgiving thing about Petrapole, where grimy trucks stretch fender to fender for miles, often waiting a week or more before moving across the Broken Boat River to Bangladesh.

abstract: UMBRELLAS were the only concession to wind and rain on a recent Saturday afternoon along Astoria's Steinway Street, where a seemingly unending expanse of small shops and eating places of every description fairly bristled with shoppers undeterred by the weather.         With its brightly colored canopies and double-parked cars, Steinway Street is only one of several main thoroughfares in Astoria, a Greek-American stronghold in northwestern Queens known for its shopping, about 200 restaurants, night life, affordability and good subway connection to Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: UMBRELLAS were the only concession to wind and rain on a recent Saturday afternoon along Astoria's Steinway Street, where a seemingly unending expanse of small shops and eating places of every description fairly bristled with shoppers undeterred by the weather.

abstract: New York City school officials say city's public schools are more crowded than at any time since height of Baby Boom four decades ago, forcing them to secure classroom space anywhere they can find it, especially in unused commercial buildings across city; Chancellor Rudy Crew and others say there are 91,000 students more than system's 1,100 schools were built to house, or enough to fill every school building in Washington or Denver; enrollment has climbed by average of 20,000 students in each of last six years to highest point since 1976 and has been fed, in part, by stream of young immigrants from Mexico, Dominican Republic and Asia and increasing number of students who spend more than four years in high school; graph (M)
snippet: New York City school officials say city's public schools are more crowded than at any time since height of Baby Boom four decades ago, forcing them to secure classroom space anywhere they can find it, especially in unused commercial buildings acro...
lead_paragraph: New York City's public schools are so crowded this year that thousands of their 1.06 million students will report to class next week at such unlikely places as a converted World War II torpedo factory in Brooklyn, a renovated department store in Queens, the upper floors of the Town Hall theater in midtown Manhattan and dozens of temporary aluminum trailers scattered in schoolyards across the city.

abstract: Today, at least to her husband, Shelley Buchanan of Washington was the "Cajun Queen, the Belle of the Bayou."         And Patrick J. Buchanan himself, at least to about 150 cheering supporters here, was suddenly a conservative champion with a strong chance to win the Republican nomination for President.
lead_paragraph: Today, at least to her husband, Shelley Buchanan of Washington was the "Cajun Queen, the Belle of the Bayou."

abstract: Sunlight squeezed through the woven rattan walls of Ibu Pesur's hut as she sat on its earthen floor whipping a wooden shuttlecock back and forth on a rough-hewn loom. Unfurling before her stretched a panel of fabric, a chromatic splash against the dull dirt floor.         In neighboring huts, down neat gravel paths fringed by coconut palms, the clatter and shoosh of shuttlecocks mingled with the yelp of children's voices, the call of a tradesman and the rainy season's distant thunder. Walking barefoot down a path, Ibu Marsihun, a 24-year-old woman in a brilliant batik print sarong, peeked in Ms. Pesur's hut to check on her neighbor's weaving.
lead_paragraph: Sunlight squeezed through the woven rattan walls of Ibu Pesur's hut as she sat on its earthen floor whipping a wooden shuttlecock back and forth on a rough-hewn loom. Unfurling before her stretched a panel of fabric, a chromatic splash against the dull dirt floor.

abstract: Twenty years ago the United Nations held a conference in Vancouver to talk about a worrying world trend toward urbanization, especially the uncontrolled growth of cities in some of the poorest countries.         That conference, held during the height of the cold war, swiftly descended into ideological bickering between industrialized nations and the third world, backed by the Soviet bloc. It ended with a statement of grandiose demands, almost none of which were fulfilled.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago the United Nations held a conference in Vancouver to talk about a worrying world trend toward urbanization, especially the uncontrolled growth of cities in some of the poorest countries.

headline.main: Hope, and Pragmatism, for U.N. Cities Conference
headline.print_headline: Hope, and Pragmatism, for U.N. Cities Conference

abstract: Many days Tongris Situmorang, in his blue baseball hat with a large X on the  front, hangs around the gates of the enormous Nike sport shoe factory here, talking to friends leaving the assembly lines at the end of the work day.         The gangly 22-year-old used to work inside the well-guarded gates, but five months ago he was dismissed for organizing workers to demand more than the 4,600 rupiah they are paid each day, about $2.10, the Government-dictated minimum wage. Then, after being dismissed, he was locked in a room at the plant and interrogated for seven days by the military, which demanded to know more about his labor activities.
lead_paragraph: Many days Tongris Situmorang, in his blue baseball hat with a large X on the front, hangs around the gates of the enormous Nike sport shoe factory here, talking to friends leaving the assembly lines at the end of the work day.

abstract: THERE IS HELL HERE IN PARADISE. AND TONY WHEELER -- the multimillionaire co-founder of the Lonely Planet travel empire and trailblazing patron saint of the world's backpackers and adventure travelers -- has journeyed halfway across  the South Pacific to ferret it out.         The rail-thin 49-year-old Briton is standing on a lush stretch of the Rue du  Pont Neuf in Papeete, the capital of French Polynesia and the largest city on the island of Tahiti. The scene is just as Gauguin left it, the warm, moist sea  air perfumed by cascades of hibiscus and jasmine.
lead_paragraph: THERE IS HELL HERE IN PARADISE. AND TONY WHEELER -- the multimillionaire co-founder of the Lonely Planet travel empire and trailblazing patron saint of the world's backpackers and adventure travelers -- has journeyed halfway across the South Pacific to ferret it out.

headline.print_headline: The End of the World on 10 Tugriks a Day

abstract: ASA BASAYEV BELIEVES she saw him. "I remember him because he was very big and a little bit heavy," she said. We were standing on the front steps of the burned-out municipal building in Samashki, a small agricultural town in war-battered western Chechnya, and Basayev, an elderly woman with piercing gray  eyes, was pointing toward the debris-strewn main street. "I saw him passing right by here," she said. I had come to Samashki, or what was left of it, with a small entourage -- a driver, a photographer and a translator -- and a question: What happened to Fred Cuny?         At the time of my conversation with Basayev, in early November, it had been seven months since Cuny, perhaps America's preeminent disaster-relief specialist, and three of his colleagues had disappeared in Chechnya -- and nearly three months since the international efforts to find them had been called off. They were presumed dead. The manhunt, one of the most extraordinary in recent times, had not uncovered where they had been killed or why.
lead_paragraph: ASA BASAYEV BELIEVES she saw him. "I remember him because he was very big and a little bit heavy," she said. We were standing on the front steps of the burned-out municipal building in Samashki, a small agricultural town in war-battered western Chechnya, and Basayev, an elderly woman with piercing gray eyes, was pointing toward the debris-strewn main street. "I saw him passing right by here," she said. I had come to Samashki, or what was left of it, with a small entourage -- a driver, a photographer and a translator -- and a question: What happened to Fred Cuny?

abstract: Jackson Heights, Queens, residents mourn planned closing of Jackson Heights Hospital by new owner, New York Hospital Care Network; small community hospital mainly serves area residents, many on Medicare or Medicaid; owner cites need to cut costs; map; graph; photos (M)
snippet: Jackson Heights, Queens, residents mourn planned closing of Jackson Heights Hospital by new owner, New York Hospital Care Network; small community hospital mainly serves area residents, many on Medicare or Medicaid; owner cites need to cut costs; ...
lead_paragraph: A lone guard watched over the lobby at Jackson Heights Hospital in Queens, detachedly pointing the infrequent visitor to two slow elevators. Behind him, the hospital's one telephone operator sat in a small office. They were the only people on the first floor, where in room after room, green beds were empty, eerily appropriate symbols for a hospital that is closing.

headline.main: Health Care Shift In Jackson Heights
headline.kicker: Neighbors Mourn Loss Of Hospital In Queens
headline.print_headline: Health Care Shift In Jackson Heights
